content.body:
Hello! I have a question, I have this code working if its run from a browser:
 
```
const client = sdk.createClient({baseUrl: "https://matrix-dev.mydomain.com"});
const user2 = await client.login("org.matrix.login.jwt", { token });                              
console.log(user2);
```

But if I run this code from nodejs. it throws an 'Error: Server returned 403 error'. I have the synapse server behind an AWS ALB. On node.js I got it working if I put the IP and port of the container like HTTP://123.123.123.123:8008, but I cannot rely on this as it will be changing over time. At first, I thought it was a reverse proxy issue, but it's working from the web browser and headers are being forwarded properly. I also have port 8448 forwarded to the container and open.

I am thinking this might be some security setting in the configuration file but tbh I am a bit lost.
content.formatted_body:
Hello! I have a question, I have this code working if its run from a browser:

const client = sdk.createClient({baseUrl: "https://matrix-dev.mydomain.com"});
const user2 = await client.login("org.matrix.login.jwt", { token });                              
console.log(user2);

But if I run this code from nodejs. it throws an 'Error: Server returned 403 error'. I have the synapse server behind an AWS ALB. On node.js I got it working if I put the IP and port of the container like HTTP://123.123.123.123:8008, but I cannot rely on this as it will be changing over time. At first, I thought it was a reverse proxy issue, but it's working from the web browser and headers are being forwarded properly. I also have port 8448 forwarded to the container and open.

I am thinking this might be some security setting in the configuration file but tbh I am a bit lost.

content.body: (I managed to get request signing working in my Elixir library just the other day.)

Try sending the request to another server that you control, but add some logging lines on the other server to see what it's expecting. e.g. see what `json_object` is in the `process_request` function in `synapse/crypto/keyring.py`, and make sure it matches your `signed_json`

content.body: Also, it should be `"method": "PUT"` instead of `"GET"`

content.body: Are you actually doing `"uri": "/target"`, or is `/target` replaced by the actual URL?

m.new_content.formatted_body:
Hello, so, I'm unable to sign an EDU successfully. I'm getting {'errcode': 'M_UNAUTHORIZED', 'error': "Invalid signature for server konqi.work with key ed25519:a_KAgK: Unable to verify signature for konqi.work: <class 'nacl.exceptions.BadSignatureError'> Signature was forged or corrupt"}, with the following Python v3 code:

import requests
import signedjson.key
import signedjson.sign

import dolphin.random

session = requests.session()
RANDOM_TXN = dolphin.random.random_string(5)

unsigned_json = {
    "method": "GET",
    "uri": "/target",
    "origin": "konqi.work",
    "destination": "matrix.org",
    "content": {
        "origin": "konqi.work",
        "origin_server_ts": 0,
        "edus": [
            {
                "edu_type": "m.typing",
                "content": {
                    "room_id": "!ehXvUhWNASUkSLvAGP:matrix.org",
                    "user_id": "@dolphin:konqi.work",
                    "typing": True
                }
            }
        ]
    }
}
signing_key = signedjson.key.decode_signing_key_base64(algorithm="ed25519", version="a_KAgK",
                                                       key_base64="REDACTED")
signed_json = signedjson.sign.sign_json(unsigned_json, "konqi.work",
                                        signing_key=signing_key)
encoded_verify_key = signedjson.key.encode_verify_key_base64(signedjson.key.get_verify_key(signing_key))
print(signed_json["signatures"]["konqi.work"]["ed25519:a_KAgK"])
print(session.put("https://matrix.konqi.work/_matrix/federation/v1/send/%s" % RANDOM_TXN, json=signed_json, headers={
    "Authorization": "X-Matrix origin=%s,key=\"%s\",sig=\"%s\"" % (
        "konqi.work", "ed25519:a_KAgK", signed_json["signatures"]["konqi.work"]["ed25519:a_KAgK"]
    )
}).json())

content.formatted_body:
Hello, so, I'm unable to sign an EDU successfully. I'm getting {'errcode': 'M_UNAUTHORIZED', 'error': "Invalid signature for server konqi.work with key ed25519:a_KAgK: Unable to verify signature for konqi.work: <class 'nacl.exceptions.BadSignatureError'> Signature was forged or corrupt"}, with the following Python v3 code:

import requests
import signedjson.key
import signedjson.sign

import dolphin.random

session = requests.session()
RANDOM_TXN = dolphin.random.random_string(5)

unsigned_json = {
    "method": "GET",
    "uri": "/target",
    "origin": "konqi.work",
    "destination": "matrix.org",
    "content": {
        "origin": "konqi.work",
        "origin_server_ts": 0,
        "edus": [
            {
                "edu_type": "m.typing",
                "content": {
                    "room_id": "!ehXvUhWNASUkSLvAGP:matrix.org",
                    "user_id": "@dolphin:konqi.work",
                    "typing": True
                }
            }
        ]
    }
}
signing_key = signedjson.key.decode_signing_key_base64(algorithm="ed25519", version="a_KAgK",
                                                       key_base64="REDACTED")
signed_json = signedjson.sign.sign_json(unsigned_json, "konqi.work",
                                        signing_key=signing_key)
encoded_verify_key = signedjson.key.encode_verify_key_base64(signedjson.key.get_verify_key(signing_key))
print(signed_json["signatures"]["konqi.work"]["ed25519:a_KAgK"])
print(session.put("https://matrix.konqi.work/_matrix/federation/v1/send/%s" % RANDOM_TXN, json=signed_json, headers={
    "Authorization": "X-Matrix origin=%s,key=\"%s\",sig=\"%s\"" % (
        "konqi.work", "ed25519:a_KAgK", signed_json["signatures"]["konqi.work"]["ed25519:a_KAgK"]
    )
}).json())

content.body: With a limit of 5, I'd expect that you'd still mostly be seeing state events from the creation of the room.  You can paginate forward, using the `end` field as your new `from` parameter, or you can set a filter so that it only returns `m.room.message` events.
content.formatted_body: With a limit of 5, I'd expect that you'd still mostly be seeing state events from the creation of the room. You can paginate forward, using the end field as your new from parameter, or you can set a filter so that it only returns m.room.message events.

content.body: I have set the limit to 5 but unable to view the message parameters
May i set the limit to 5?
You asked for one event (`limit=1`), so it gave you one event, which happened to be the create event.
content.formatted_body: You asked for one event (limit=1), so it gave you one event, which happened to be the create event.

content.body: Unable to view the text messages
omit the filter or specify one which is inclusive of the things you want.
For text messages what should i do?
if the room is encrypted the server won't be able to see whether a message has media or not, so will not be able to include them
so those won't be text messages, those will be media messages only
Your filter says to only include messages which contain a URL
